clean_comment: with more waves of troops approaching the beach the airmen decide to retreat and reorganize their heavy weapons   the Japanese are finally able to push off the beaches but are completely exhausted and unable to chase after the retreating Americans   both sides consolidate their positions inland and decide to wait for the other to make a move   the Navy is sent in to reinforce the Air Corps along with the Marine detachment   the sailors having no combat experience are simply given standing orders to quote just follow the Marines and do whatever they do   naturally unsuited for combat the sailors neglect to build defensive fortifications and spend their first night on the line making campfires smoking and talking loudly   the Japanese commander is bewildered at this activity and thinks its a ruse to bait them into a trap coming to the conclusion that no force would be stupid enough to act so carelessly unless they were doing it on purpose   this idea was further reinforced by the sailors bright yellow uniforms as the Japs were now convinced that they were up against some sort of special forces unit that wanted to be found   now completely psyched out by what could be best described as an average boy scout camping expedition the Japanese think theyll outsmart the Americans at their own game and decide to let the Americans attack them first   this plan backfires spectacularly as the time bought by literally doing nothing allows the US to rush their armored units to the beach and they counterattack with the full force of their stuart tanks and bren gun carriers   the Japanese are quite literally pushed off the shore with many choosing to commit suicide by jumping off the cliffs   an entire brigade of Japs roughly 800 men who were hardened veterans of the war in China are completely destroyed by a force of Allied units that had collectively never fired a single shot in anger before the battle

MONTGOMERY Ala July 1 2022  Today an Alabama law prohibiting state and local enforcement of federal gun control by executive order goes into effect The enactment of this legislation takes a small step toward ending some federal acts that infringe on the right to keep and bear arms within the state    Sen Gerald Allen introduced Senate Bill 2 SB2 on Jan 11 The law prohibits any official officer employee or agent of the state or a political subdivision of the state from enforcing or administering any executive order issued by the president that limits or restricts the ownership use or possession of firearms ammunition or firearm accessories by lawabiding residents of the state The bill also bans the expenditure of state or local funds for the enforcement of the same   Hello I am writing to you from the great state of Alabama with a question about suppressors and the NFA  Our state has recently decided to refuse to enforce federal gun legislation as unConstitutional In other words the state and local law enforcement refuses to cooperate with the BATF on enforcing the NFA and similar infringements on the Constitution  Id like to obtain a suppressor for night hunting but I dont want to comply with 2A infringements like the NFA Should I go ahead and buildbuy a suppressor without any paperwork or is it not worth the heat from the revenue boys There are loopholes where they could maybe enforce it anyways

The T72 just isnt very good its an obsolete tank based on an obsolete masswarfare doctrine for a war which never happened NATO MBTs like the M1 and its derivatives are all much better because they were always intended to be individually more costly but to have a qualitiative advantage They prioritised turret armour situational awareness mobility and firepoweralong with having a more functional microelectronics industry which allowed for more complicated FCS and situational awareness systems such as thermals and in modern times tank GPS The soviets went for a light cheap easily deployable but cost effective tank which prioritised having as low a profile and weight as possible while trying to fit as much armour and as big a gun as the chasis would allow The larger NATO MBTs also allowed them to more easily accommodate upgrades over their service life unlike cramped soviet tanks whose small size severely restricts what they can be fitted with That and NATO having a much better electronics industry and the collapse of the USSR devastating industry in Russia Theres an additional issue of the Russian armour values looking good in theory at least for the 1980s but in practice they offered very incomplete coverage again due to the small size Whereas a NATO MBT has much more comprehensive frontal armour coverage in addition to not having the autoloader which sends you to space

All other aspects of design quality being equal in a traditional baffle based dry suppressor performance comes heavily down to internal volume A firearm creates a volume of very high pressure gas in a contained tube the expansion of which drives the bullet and most of the sound comes from the gas entering free atmosphere behind the bullet at high speed a tiny amount comes from the supersonic crack of the bullet itself but not much A standard suppressor provides contained space for that gas to expand and cool before entering the atmosphere more slowly and over more time vs all at once which makes it quieter If a can has more internal volume it has more space to hold all the gas and let it cool  In a cylinder centered around the barrel there is a limit to how much its practical to increase the diameter before its so high it really interferes with even suppressor height sights or optics So to get more volume you make the suppressor longer But in general handguns have a lot more space below the barrel then above in terms of not getting in the way So a noncylinder suppressor can have the same internal volume with a shorter length by expanding vertically downwards Since shorter length can be desirable in handguns that can be a decent trade  The other approach to short is to use wetwipe based designs but those are more irritating to use so still tradeoffs

I agree OP Personally I think its just a dumb consumer fad that mostly appeals to 1 of 2 groups   The first is gun noobs who dont know that much about guns They see these fold up guns and think theyre amazing for bugging out because they dont know enough about guns to see how limited the utility of folding is why is this better than just separating the upper and lower Is it faster to deploy Does it take up less space The answer to both is generally no Thats not even getting into what a dumb concept bugging out is in the first place The idea of abandoning all of your possessions and resources in favor a vague unknown wilderness is generally stupid and ill conceived   The second group is gun dorks who want to pretend that they are James Bond They see a folding gun and have fantasies of walking into a hotel with a brief case and deploying the gun like some super assassin in a movie to take out the bad guy If we are being honest this is the primary use of guns like this For nerds to feel cool as they imagine themselves doing something with these guns that they will never ever do

what thought processes do you fellas walk through when contemplating a can  If its a handgun cartridge can then there isnt much to it because the pressure is so low If its handgun only then just get whatever is modern made by a quality brand and fits targets for weightsize or maybe if you want oddball features like noncylinder If you plan to use it on PCCs with high rate of fire and for rifle subsonics or stuff like that pick something manufacturer rated for it but thats still easy  For rifles it gets more complex Absolute suppression performance varies way more but on top of that is a lot of factors involved in the platform you want to use Semi or manual Where on the hunting to range toy spectrum If semi do youcan you have an AGB Stuff like that helps you figure out how you need to balance noise vs backpressure size and weight Then go read independent reviews like at pew science that measure that shit  Finally in all cases double check warranties Most can makers in America have pretty good ones but some are better then others Also double check what the repairability story is it matters if the serial d bit is well protected and separate from the business bits even with a gold warranty thanks to the bullshit of the NFA

Part 12  Generally the best way to get into this unless you have one really specific discipline in mind is to get 34 guns that generally cover your bases and then move from there  Youre going to want a 22 lr carbine to practice and learn fundamentals on while slowly building a tolerance for muzzle report to avoid developing a flinch If you really want to you can get a 22 for ridiculously cheap old squirrel guns from the 60s through the 90s can be had for a couple hundred or even less at a pawn shop OR you can get a really nice one because thisll probably be the thing you shoot the most BY FAR if you want to practice diligently A Ruger 1022 has been the default choice for about 30 years I personally have a backpacker model with a Vortex red dot because I can throw it in my backpack and yeet squirrels once I set up my camp wandering around in the mountains but theres loads of other good choices on the market GSG makes some really cool guns that look kind of like an MP5 SavageLakefield make a decent gun and theres a couple companies making AR7 style survival rifles if you want something you can throw in a river and still use just off the top of my head 22 lr lever actions are also wicked cool and loads of fun to snipe soda cans and ground squirrels with  You want a shotgun a twelve gauge pump gun can easily be the most versatile tool in your safe if you have the barrels and ammunition for it A shotgun can take everything from squirrels and partridge to ducks and geese to deer and predators that walk on two legs Bird shot is cheap and good for getting food in a pinch buckshot inside 40 yards is one hell of a hammer looking for a nail and a slug under ideal conditions out of a rifled shotgun barrel can potentially be accurate out to 100 yards Clay shooting is also a neat way to practice shooting moving targets and enjoy a sunny day They have a small magazine but theyre light simple and damn near indestructible

The base Scout Rifle requirements and concept as dictated by Cooper made sense for the state of the typical civilian or nonSWAT law enforcement rifle shooter at the time they were written  Keep in mind this was a time when shit like red dots holo sights and LPVOs were virtually nonexistent civvie AR derivatives were insanely expensive andor unreliable and even owning any semiauto military rifle design newer than the Garand and its descendants was seen as unnecessary prepper kook shit and somewhat frowned upon by most mainstream civvie gun owners even in the US  In that context Coopers original requirements make perfect sense Nowadays everything has pretty much done a 180 and a halfway decent AR with a halfway decent LPVO holo or red dot does everything Coopers scout rifle concept is intended to do way better

I clean mine every time I put about 500 rounds through it total or it gets wet or visibly filthy just to keep it from getting totally trashed by rust I definitely dont clean any of mine nearly as much as I do my other guns When I do Its usually just a quick take the barrel off spray with CLP swab with a mop wipe down the outside CLP inside the receiver through the ejection port wipe inside with a cloth wipe outside reassemble as opposed to the field strips I do on my other guns every time I come back from the range and the detailed strips I do every 1000 rounds or once a year whichever comes first

It was my first attempt at glass bedding as well and I learned a few things Its a messy sticky process so really tape off all the outside of the stock because the bedding is kind of um stringy Think like melted cheese that stretches and its easy to drop little bits of it that are impossible to get off The other thing is that it actually takes very little bedding The fit on that stock was good enough that even after gnarling it and sanding a bit I think I only used like half a teaspoon or something  Also that stock honestly looks better on your stainless finish rifle than it did on my blued one As for saving the gun part no I throw away a lot parts and sometimes I wish I hadnt or have a use for it The thing is I would be buried in old gun parts No Id rather have a clutter free house

To give a direct example of something really using that and combining with integral for even more gains heres a Maxim 9 which I have one of It has a 44 barrel about the same as a Glock 17 gen5 45 barrel which then has an overall length of 795 Meanwhile the Maxim 9 is 1075 inches so the entire gun is only 28 longer then a conventional full size handgun Despite that it suppresses very well sub140 with any standard 9mm ammo all while having a flat top you can use conventional height normal glock irons on Part of the reason for that is the suppressor stretches way down below the bore so the total volume is still high Again you can get short cylinders that work an Aurora 2 is only 33 long but it uses wipes  Part of the reason I really hate suppressors being on the NFA is how it kills the market for innovative designs thatd be really nice for suppressing with CC Itd be totally possible to do an integral noncylinder 380 handgun that was subcompact in dimensions But itll never happen under the NFA as it stands even the Maxim is dead now which is a true bummer I love that gun

Do you happen to have any suggestions to help narrow my options for 45 cans  Ill say up front that Ive shrunk down a lot in the last few years aiming to be at just 34 total calibers with 9mm as my handgun one so I cant tell you exactly what the best 45 is now my knowledge is years out of date However here is how Id think of it and then walking through it 1 Performance handgun round suppression tends to be pretty similar without major asterisks as I said earlier so this isnt a huge differentiator One thing to be cautious of ties in with the next factor size a lot of cans these days are modular where you can have a short and long config The advertised suppression is always long and thats always the only one that is going to be decent So dont get fooled by places that highlight both short config length and long config suppression 2 Size This one varies a lot more and does matter when tied to performance Anyone can suppress by just throwing size and mass at it but a can that suppresses to a given level while also being compact is punching above its weight so to speak A lot of top 45 cans are big like 810 3 Warranty limited lifetime is table stakes in the US can market imo  So going through a bunch of places AAC Huxwrx Resilient I actually think good ol SilencerCo and the Omega 45K looks pretty decent At 64 long its way way below what Im seeing from others but still is   Anyway dunno but hope that helps a little Good luck anon first can is always the most painful Make sure to buy with a trust

While I love the 336 dearly and deer hunt with one myself when off the prairies and in the woodsmountains the Ruger ranch would probably be the better choice between those two 762x39 is more widely available and cheaper giving him something easier to spend time practicing with 762x39 has a slightly flatter trajectory at range while 3030 can take heavier bullets that are better for knocking things down and less likely to icepick Both curve like a rainbow beyond 200 yards and both will easily kill anything whitetail sized or smaller  For alternate choices A 223 bolt gun as previously suggested by at least one other person will also be good for whacking prairie dogs at range A 38357 mag 1894 lever gun will hold more ammunition than either a 336 or a bolt gun and is fantastically fun to learn on I speak from experience The little 38 special will take small game easily and makes target practice very affordable and a 357 magnum out of an 185 barrel will easily take deer and coyotes I can hit an 8 plate at 100 yards with mine through iron sights or a red dot It also carries light and if you practice with it you can shoot almost as fast as a semi the key factor being itll take practice and in the interim gives Billy time to learn safety and discipline Such a gun also pairs fantastically with a revolver and the two together work well going through brush looking for hogs later in life Its not terribly practical if you are willing to consider semiautos but within the confines of your prompt they might make up for it in being fun A 17 HMR or 22 magnum Savages B17 and B22 mag rifles in particular will also put a coyote down with a good shot and are even cheaper to shoot but at this point start to strain the conditions you put out Very light easy to carry and laser beam accurate but will struggle to penetrate a shoulder on a coyote and certainly arent what Id choose for taking on a human

factories were already tooled to make the M1919 they M1919 was already used in about a dozen different roles so might as well use it for infantry as well and save on costs the M1919 was already good enough for their purposes  swapping over the entire assembly line to produce MG42s instead of M1919s would be questionable even if they wanted a gun with 1000 rounds per minute which itself was a dubious proposition      the US ended up using the M60 after the war which was a hodge podge of german and US design elements and after the M60 adopted the M240 which was another hodge podge of the MG42 and the BAR       It might be for propaganda purposes or maybe its genuinely reflective of Army thinking at the time  the latter a high ROF is pretty useless outside of trying to hit airplanes and by the time WW2 rolled around planes flew so fast and so high even 50cal weapons were having trouble hitting them and cannons were starting to take over  pretty much all modern GPMGs have a ROF between 600 and 800 rounds per minute except the MG3 which will be replaced by the MG5 with a more tame rate of fire

Why didnt the allies copy the MG34 and MG42 during ww2  It wasnt that big a deal People jerk off these things in DBZ style power level debates but in practice a machine gun is a machine gun a DP28 Bren or M1919 will do the same job in 99 of circumstances The true genius of these things is in the logistics department One machine gun for all roles infantry tripod mounted vehicle mounted Reason why there wasnt a deep pressing need for this is because the Allies were not starting from scratch like 30s Germany they had hundreds of thousands of ready manufactured guns at the wars beginning Basically it would be a huge logistical hassle to introduce a new gun into production and then slowly integrate it into the the armed forces as production becomes available not to mention the years of testing Since these things are supposed to ease logistical burden well in the middle of the war wasnt the time

The topic of giving guns to kids for selfdefense is a highly debated and sensitive issue Several factors need to be carefully considered such as the childs age maturity understanding of firearm safety and the context of the environment  Legally the minimum age for firearm possession and use varies by country and state However regardless of the law many would argue that children may not have the emotional or mental maturity to handle firearms responsibly  Moreover introducing firearms to children for selfdefense might inadvertently increase the risk of accidents misuse or escalation of violence in certain situations The emphasis should be on teaching children conflict resolution deescalation tactics and seeking adult help when faced with threats  Ideally promoting gun safety education and responsible gun ownership within families can be valuable However the decision to arm children for selfdefense should be approached cautiously considering the potential risks and the childs readiness to handle such a responsibility

US and german tactics were really similar only differences coming from the weapons they were provided with  each squad had their own machine gun BAR or MG42 which they would use to allow the rest of the squad to maneuver  while an additional machine gun on a tripod provided an additional base of fire M1919 or MG42 a US squad would have one BAR gunner reload while the other fired to keep sustained fire but the end result was similar to a MG42  it was the brits who had a radically different structure each squad had no MGs at all the brens were collected in the MG section so each rifle squad had anemic firepower but all their MGs were directed by the platoon leader

bolt action is king  reliable   bolt aciton   simple to maintain   simple to repair   simple mechanism   simple to operate   easy to learn how to use   most dont even need to learn how to because they did operation bolt locks as a kid or imagining it in their fantasies   literally every boys dream   even if they didnt play with locks they played games or have seen movies and therefor seen the action in work   less likely to fail due to fouling   better for using improvised propellants because of lack susceptibility to fouling agents   most will be able to use black powder reliably especially when combined with smoothbore   been around for over a century and a half as result there are hundreds of models   meaning they are easy to procure   parts are easy to find when using generic make   several different marks exist for almost all bolt action models   parts require little machining or 3d printing skill to learn to make    computer controlled or guided machining benches exist meaning little to no skill is actually needed   digital patterns for parts can be found online or requested on forums   usually not targeted as much by antigun lobbies because of their perceived harmlessness when compared to semiauto rifles   usually easy to get in most of the world because of this and because legislation is not as hard on them in most of europa or the wider world   combine with black powder and smoothbore in wood furniture and some countries and states wont even count them the same as other guns   because of the above license is much easier to get heck you can even get a firearms license and buy one in china all you need is a hunting and sporting license which tells you how easy they are to get

Ok hear me out I am going to play the devils advocate hre for a while  Justified has a lot of meanings   Some people think that protecting your life is justified They are right Some people thing that protecting the life of your family and loved ones is justified They are right Some people think that protecting the property that is immediately necessary for their livelihoods think settlers protecting their pots pans horses tills axes their seed grain you know stuff that you ABSOLUTELY NEED in order to survive is justified They are right  But what about some nonessential stuff A stereo equipment A Widescreen TV A silverware table set  thats the point where some people start thinking Its not right to take a human life for a stereo set Thats where the ideas of reasonable selfdefense start to overlap with gun control   Equating ALL your property as vital for my survival is a psychological failure No you do not need your TV in order to survive Its not part of your livelihood Your life will not suffer catastrophic end and collapse because you lost your TVstereo If you lost a piece of equipment that is VITAL PART of your livelihood it would be more understandable Thats how you make your living   But killing a person because of a stereo or a tv Thats the point where the gun control thinking begins you are going too far Not ALL property is worth protecting with deadly force

Federal HST wasnt developed until after the 1986 Miami Shootout The FBIs gel test doesnt even attempt to determine whether a bullet is a manstopper or not because they figured that its impossible to replicate the psychological aspect of being shot in a lab setting The 1218 of penetration standard is just supposed to represent how deep a handgun bullet needs to travel in the human body to eventually cause a catastrophic loss in blood pressure So yes 9mm out of a 3 barrel will eventually kill you It might be 3 minutes after being shot or 3 hours later on the operating table The question should be does it actually effectively stop a threat in a timely manner during a gunfight

Should I just go ahead and obtain a suppressor without complying to the NFA which I believe infringes on the Constitution or would it not be worth attracting the attention of federal agents who could potentially selectively enforce it despite Alabama being a 2A sanctuary  Its not worth it then is my simple answer The fact is that while mildly irritating it simply isnt that big a deal nor are you saving anything in particular and on the contrary the more people openly and legally own suppressors and have no fear about using them about taking them to the range and letting others seeuse them the more likely it is we can get them taken off the NFA It builds public knowledge and awareness and political pressure countering Hollywood bullshit So I genuinely think the path towards making things better goes through open political engagement Rome wasnt built in a day the kinds of gun friendly environments we have now vs 40 years ago is the result of decades of steady work  From a selfish point of view I just dont want to have to think about it if I need to use a gun Whether vs person or animal if you have a perfectly reasonable shoot the stress of having a totally unnecessary felony mixed in feels completely stupid to me for two hundred fucking bux I want to just reach for whatever and use it no matter who is around

I dont think its that they didnt like 556 Its more that narcos and the like can afford newer plates so 556 simply cant pen that at distance The Mexican army figured out that most narcos are garbage shots so their doctrine is to pick them off with accurate fire from ranges that battle rifles are effective at Narcos mostly have AK and AR platform guns in intermediate cartridges and just spray and pray Most engagements between the Mexican military and narcos are actually in mountainous zones or in hilly fields where battle rifles shine Also in urban areas NATO 762 pens cover better Its why theyve kept the G3 in production The FX05 was designed to be able to handle larger rounds than 556 from its onset The Mexican army actually wanted the SCAR family as their standard rifle way back in the early 2000s but FN wasnt allowing them to license produce it back then so they first went with the G36 then built the FX05 as a weird halfway between the SCAR and G36 Now apparently its held up because Mexico cant figure out if they want 65 sneedmoor or 68 as their future primary cartridge The lower recoil flat trajectory 40mm grenade launcher is however well into its final stages They use a medium velocity round similar in concept to what the Germans are going to use in their SSW40 grenade rifle

I thought my new Ruger scout was a Mauser action  Depends on how autistic you want to get   Do I not know what a Mauser action is  Maybe   Is my Ruger scout not a threaded Mauser action bolt action  No not really   I really like the action and rifle whatever it is  Nothing wrong with that  Basically depending on what you mean in context Mauser action can be anything between an unmodified bolt action designed and produced in house by Mauser Gmbh or under license and an action that mostly works like an M9598etc action Most people mean having identical working principles to a Mauser action and that covers a lot of ground This common definition includes guns like the 1903 Springfield the pre64 M70s various CZsBRNOs etc even though theyre not completely identical to actions designed and produced by Mauser       Why they do be like that  For people who want iron sights but dont care about actually shooting with them Most rifles made in the last 70 years or so that have irons are awful to actually use the irons on because the combs are set up to be used with scopes      God I wish they did as well       Zastava M70 or whatever it is called now that is still in production is a 11 of the BRNO mauser  Not really no I got one because thats what I heard but when I got my hands on a BRNO the 72122 or 2122 or whatever the hell the actual name is the ones with butterknife bolt handles that were manufactured from 194555 before they moved to the ZG47 and even setting aside the quality of the results the differences in design were were stark The 21 is very obviously a last hurrah of prewar prescope sporter design the stock is extremely slim with a low comb it has noticeable cast with a small cheekswell and is just shy of being straight It has double set triggers excellent open irons and a German claw mount The Zastava has a very modern stock and an action thats not nearly as refined in function

IS2 was an interesting tank In terms of crew survivability comfort tactical awareness it was pretty fucking garbage Fuel tanks surrounding the crew who were crammed in even more like sardines than in a T34 with no real ability for the driver to see and barely any visibility for anyone but the commander Sound awful but that was so they could cram as much gun and armor onto the thing as possible And the two piece ammo also blew chunks for tank engagements or any high octane fighting in general but it meant whatever it did hit died They built about 4000 in the war and lost half of those in combat so they were hardly some impregnable super weapon but especially considering they were produced at the tail end of the war not the start thats a lot of heavy tanks and quantity of a weapon is important just by itself As a breakthrough tank it showed obviously decent performance I think its a bit overhyped for what it was but I wouldnt say its without merit It also didnt break down constantly so huge plus I would make the argument that heavy tanks in ww2 were a mistake on the whole Breakthrough tanks like the Tiger and IS2 were good when used appropriately which was offensive force multipliers tip of the spear type deals They were not useful for nor particularly good at defensive engagements on the whole even if they might have had some favorable kds in doing so Its all about resources and opportunity cost and in a large way the IS2 was a lot of opportunity cost taken to its extreme And properly deployed in the time and place when it was most beneficial to do so I do not think IS2s would have performed any better than KV1s in 1941 but they were exactly what the Soviets needed in 1944

Fwiw to my understanding the us military tried to modify the mg42 to fire 600 rpm to match the 1919 give or take a 3006 is longer than an 8mm but a fired 3006 is shorter than an unfired 8mm so failing a dud it shouldnt have any issues ejecting all else being equal   The mg42 ejects the round by a rod that goes all the way through the bolt if it doesnt hit the buffer spring hard enough it wont eject properly  To slow the rof down on an open bolt your only option is to slow the bolt down   The 3006 versions bolt moved slower to make the rof difference of about 50  The biggest problem with the guns as tested was to my understanding stovepipes as in a failure to eject I suspect they couldnt get it to slow down enough to get the proper rof and still properly eject  T Mg42 owner with 15 years gunsmithing experience

From a macro perspective the prevalence of guns increases the total risk of gun violence The more guns there are the more gun deaths there just as with automobiles The more automobiles the more automobile fatalities there are Diving down the next factor is public policy such as well developed public transit systems and mitigation measures such as strong traffic safety regulation reduce the risk of automobile fatalities This is why Arkansas has 4 times as many auto deaths per capita than New York despite New York being the same size as Arkansas but having 3x the population The last factor is overall education levels both as individuals and related to firearms and automobles Traffic deaths for those with a high school diploma or worse are sky high compared to college educated people and the same is true for gun owners  Put all three together and that is why Massachusetts has the lowest gun and automobile deaths in the country amd Mississippi has the highest of both MA has strong gun regulation low rates of ownership and high levels of education MS has the opposite

The first documented telescopic rifle sight was invented between 1835 and 1840 In a book titled The Improved American Rifle written in 1844 BritishAmerican civil engineer John R Chapman documented the first telescopic sights made by gunsmith Morgan James of Utica New York Chapman gave James the concepts and some of the design whereupon they produced the ChapmanJames sight In 1855 optician William Malcolm of Syracuse New York began producing his own telescopic sight used an original design incorporating achromatic lenses such as those used in telescopes and improved the windage and elevation adjustments These Malcolm sights were between 3 and 20 magnification possibly more Malcolms sights and those made by Vermont jeweller L M Amidon were the standard sharpshooter equipments during the American Civil War

technology develops slower the closer it is to present times   Not really It has nothing in particular to do with the present day The real maxim is that more mature technology develops slower The less mature something is the faster its going to change This is true of aircraft cars spacecraft computers smart phones firearms You name it When something new is invented the early years are taken up by rapid development and improvement As it matures development will slow down and changes become more incrimental A PC made in 2013 is more similar to one made today than one made in 1980 is to one made in 1990

no part of network centric warfare or multidomain ops has ignored the tank  deemphasised it slightly perhaps which is natural but it remains the most powerful land manoeuvre unit on the board artillery cannot replace it as artillery is too fragile and the most supplyintensive weapon around besides aircraft       just shoot over the top  youre talking about a very expensive solution to killing tanks that not even the worlds biggest and most modern army has bet fully on  no doubt ATGMs of all kinds have become the premier tank killers on the planet  that is after all the stated intent of NATO doctrine since the 70s  but that doesnt change the fact that tank guns firing APFSDS remains the fundamental capability underlying all of that because it has certain key advantages  APFSDS flies faster is mostly effective against all but the most modern of tanks is orders of magnitude cheaper has a very quick and independent firing cycle tank acquires direct LOS with target 3 seconds later its toast and very importantly is immune to most forms of hard and soft kill protection systems  nothing can decoy away a dumb ballistic projectile  the indirect fire tank gambles on NLOS for survival rather than other forms of protection I can maybe see tanks being equipped with missiles moving forward but would missiles totally replace BOTH main gun and armour no no it wouldnt

Its a Stevens 20 gauge bolt action shotgun It was 80 at a pawn shop 10 years ago and I was looking for something cheap to cut down and make a handy long gun that I could beat the shit out of and not worry about it When I got it the stock was attached by a single vertical bolt that went up through the stock and into a lug on the action The wood cracked and failed almost immediately at that attachment point resulting in the action being jammed backwards in the stock on every shot This prevented operating the bolt until you pulled the whole barrel and action back forwards If you look just in front of the magazine you can see the lightercolored wood filler where I attempted to repair the stock and the hole I drilled for a bolt to go horizontally through the stock to stop the action from moving backwards under recoil   What ended up happening is that after a few shots the cross bolt I added just ended up sheering off the welded lug on the action for the factory stock bolt Now the action had no means of being attached to the stock so I used hose clamps Its under the bolt handle so you cant see it but I put in a new cross bolt that goes behind another part of the action that holds the trigger and everything because the hose clamps dont stop the original problem of the action from getting jammed back into the stock That was worked since but I havent shot the gun in years The Rossi lever action took its place as a handy long gun to beat up

but Americans cant get over the bias that its a Soviet machine gun round that cant hit the broad side of a barn  Maybe some baby boomers held such sentiments but most Americans hunting with bottleneck cartridges already hunted with rounds and ammunition designed for hunting are already in common usage in the country  When x39 started to appear on the consumer markets it had to mingle with other rounds aside from 223 Rounds such as 270 308 3006 222 300 savage and much more were in commonality   But there is one round in particular that stands near the 762x39 cartridge 3030 Winchester The 3030 is one of the first smokeless powder cartridges to sell on the US consumer market Its been a mainstay for deer hunters since 1895 and despite being antiquated by modern standards its still a favorite among hunters in dense wooded areas in some parts of the country The cartridge is said to have killed more deer than any other in the US and that credence probably rings true considering the amount of lever guns made in it But its not just a levee gun cartridge it was a popular round for sporterdized surplus rifles and saw some love in pump action rifles revolvers and break action pistols such as the Contender  But whats led this have to do with x39 Well they share similar ballistics but the 3030 has the added benefit of greater ammo variety and legality for hunting in certain states When x39 started to arrive on the market it was all corrosive steel core surplus and the only guns that shot it were combloc arms not particularly suited for hunting deer or similar types of game Then there is laws Each stage has its own laws and regulations for hunting Many states have capacity limits caliber limits ammo restrictions and more 3030 had an easier time meeting these regulations back in the day and still does  762x39 cant compete

There hasnt been a company vs company engagement aside from a few cases The largest engagement was something like 56 tanks on each side This is a very rare situation But if we think about it the tank was originally devised to be a vehicle that could advance across the multilayered enemy defensive line with barbed wire and antipersonnel mines since AT mines didnt exist And it was originally conceived as an infantry support vehicle so there were machinegun tanks and gun tanks But their purpose was to support infantry at the field of battle from the front or the rear so the infantry could capture the enemy trenches Thats what they do now returning to tradition But in addition to that they are still used as field artillery But their semidirect or indirect firesupport role has decreased due to the nature of fighting and thanks to the fact that we got more dedicated artillery and shells In addition to that artillery reconnaissance units got saturated with drones so they function differently to how its written in manuals Nevertheless tanks are still used in this role when there is nothing else available or everything else has run out of shells Welltrained crews come are able to shoot at 12km  This is why I doubt tanks will be obsolete any time soon The pure direct fire MBT is looking a bit dated but if you want something that can get right up to the front and deliver a shell to anything within 12km with very quick travel time an artillery tank hybrid is a really good choice In 1020 years they could be doing that even further into the enemy backline by launching remote controlled glide vehicles rather than dumb shells which would make staying near the front very dangerous for things like SPGs TOS1 or air defence Itd be expensive compared with a normal shell but cheap compared with a missile

9mm Sub2000 with rather tame loads in a 33 round Glawk mag a WML and perhaps a red dot   1 Everything that will penetrate an intruder will also penetrate your apartments plywood walls Firing a single bullet at a time instead of a cloud of shot is the safer approach for not hitting anything valuable 2 The entire package is cheap if you dont freak out with the red dot and light So it wont hurt you if the gun is confiscated by the police after you had to use it  3 Its a very small light gun So its easy to wield and use within narrow hallways etc Since you can fold it down you can store it everywhere 4 It being a PCC with a rather soft recoil means everybody can use it without being a danger to himself and others

People buy a pump shoot it a few times then it sits in a closet for 40 years Most people dont find a shotgun to be comfortable shooting that frequently  If you shoot clays and participate in club or competition skeet trap etc shooting then youll either be using a OU or rarer SxS or a semiauto If you are hunting ducks its almost always a semiauto now If you are shooting the 3gun type competitions its almost always a semi For upland birds its SxS  OU  Semi as is customary Pump shotguns tend to occupy one of three positions among gunowners and shooters one of the first guns they buy because everybody recommends a pump their innawoods defensive weapon youll see a lot of mossbergs and 870s up north for polar bear defence or their home defence weapon  All three situations warrants very little actual shooting of the pump shotguns They are usable but unsuitable for the other use cases mentioned earlier Get a Mossberg 500590590A1 or a Remington 870 produced before 1994 preferably a nice Wingmaster since they are so smooth and barrels can be changed to whatever length you want with a simple swap This is just for formality as you want to own a pump shotgun Or to let others shoot it because pumps are iconic or whatever But consider getting a proper Italian semiauto either from Beretta or a nice Benelli M4 for that smooth as a buck naked snake feeling

You cannot inspect quality into a product A process has an inherent ability to producing a result For example a bolt is milled out of Carpenter 158 stock So you decide to run it through an inspection machine but you cannot measure the first and last two inches of the 20 foot bar of raw material so maybe that is scrap or you keep it and thats on extra bolt per 20 foot section High quality control throws it away and not so high QC just omits the inspection completely but the quality of the material is the same either way In this case you are only losing a single digit  of material but it adds up So do tool changes of cutting tools More frequent  more money These are economic decisions It costs more but should it cost twice as much I dont think so in this case What will a defect cost It is different in every case It is the difference between having a flat on Saturday on the way to the store or corner 3 at Laguna Seca on MotoGP weekend Every AR part is critical but failure is designed to occur where it can be easily fixed in the field If your life depends on it 3000 isnt a lot of money to know it goes boom but the chance of a failure happening going from 1 in 100000 to 1 in 150000 is not going to make a big difference for most I used to buy precision metal parts in the multi millions and the same companies make ARM platform parts and ammo use the same manufacturing quality lab and inspection processes The quality and precision for an AR is nothing compared to a fuel injector and every car has 48 of them and they see heat and pressure and the tolerance is 125th of a human hair so please lets not pretend that the high cost of these weapons do not include branding and sales costs not related to performance

Condolences Walther fanboys but it would not have been a PPK Heres why  Bond was written as a Cold War era MI6 operative During the Cold War the main area of operations for MI6 agents would be the Warsaw Pact countries They would enter their target countries as merchants or under some diplomatic cover This means a real Bond would have been officially working for some MI6 front who do business with the target country in question In the movies Bond was a representative of Universal Exports which was an MI6 front He carried a Walther PPK because it most closely resembled the gun all real MI6 agents would carry  Traveling under a cover identity Bond would cross the border to the Warsaw Pact member states just like any merchant or diplomat He would have a suitcase and perhaps a briefcase for business documents When crossing the border the border guards would carefully open and examine his belongings There was no way a real Bond would try to smuggle a PPK over That is an unnecessary risk Instead real MI6 operatives would have a local MI6 contact already operating in the country This is also how the KGB operated in the West They would have an armorer who would provide weapons and equipment for their operatives The armorers can only purchase local equipment definitely not Western products unlike in the movies where Bond gets his stuff from a Londonbased Q  tldr  A real Bond would be given a Makarov or PB not only because theyre the ones the local armorer can easily get but also because he needs the gun to fire local ammo and be reliable The Soviets also had a wide range of suppressed weapons designed for assassinations which the West didnt really even have at the time  tldrtldr  Real Bonds used Soviet weapons and equipment not Western

people could easily make 1020 round mags for them too  No no they fucking cant 8 rounds is the absolute maximum practical capacity for a conventional singlestack 12 gauge magazine Even if reliability concerns werent there for longer mags they are the length alone disqualifies these longer singlestack mags from use in anything other than 3gun gamer guns or range toys Mossberg was the only one who managed to actually put double stack 12ga magazine on the market but it doesnt seem to be doing too well commercially or spawning any cheaper alternatives The bigger the round especially if its rimmed the harder it is to design a reliable magazine and the smaller its capacity would be However shotgun shells are uniquely fucked in this regard because there is no universal standard of shotgun shell dimensions that all companies follow A 2 and 23 inch shell can get quite different from one manufacturer to the next in all of its important dimensions no one follows the SAAMI standard or anything like this in the way that manufacturers follow it for 9x19 or 556 Because you dont have to with a shotgun using a tube mag and a lifter But you do in a conventionally magazinefeeding notrifle chambered for shotgun shells Which not a lot of people use Which creates a feedback loop where development sale and purchase of new magazinefed shotguns is continuously disincentivized This coupled with the already vicious nature of the arms market which loves killing even old and established companies let alone newcomers means that no it wont be easy to do that shit Oh yeah and bolt action shotguns fucking suck period no one would ever make one again

Dont know much about the Winchester 1300       the winchester 1300 has some fragile plastic magazine throat   I know about the 1300 American made ones Regarding the fragile plastic part The magazine tube is pressed into a plastic piece that is itself inside the aluminum frame I own multiple 1300s from the 90s and Ive seen retired police trade ins beat to shit with broken off butt plates worn out springs and no finish On none of them has that piece ever been broken Its sandwiched between other metal parts Ive only heard of it on k and while you could break it like Glocks exploding and SIGs rusting it just isnt the problem that that k makes it out to be  There are 2 problems with the 1300 1 The guns are all old and replacement parts are increasingly difficult to find So if you do break that or any other piece its not as easy to replace 2 The aftermarket is virtually nonexistent unlike with the 870 and 590 both of which have huge aftermarket This is only an issue if you want to play with different furniture and side saddles  Other than that the 1300 is as good of a pump action as has ever existed Its super light and super smooth Just like an AR the receiver is aluminum while the bolt rotates and locks inside the barrel This set up makes the guns lighter and stronger However all that said and to anons point an old gun has parts that can break and be hard to replace So you dont buy one with the intent to abuse it   Remington 870  Everyone I personally know that has bought one in the last 30 years had it break immediately Maybe theyre better this year I dont know They were the gold standard in the 70s   590a1  Is the best pump action currently sold The only 2 downsides are weight theyre heavy and price theyre expensive  Personally Ive been thinking about getting a Stoeger Double Defense because it looks fun to shoot and more than adequate for home defense  pic related

The fear that I have with shotguns is that therell be a malfunction in a critical situation   Im going to load this thing and put it in a closet for years Temperature is going to go up and down dont have an AC vent in my closet and metal parts are going move The shotgun shells are going bulge a little The mechanical process of chambering a round is the most complicated action of any civilian gun  and then one day Im going to reach for it in a stressful lifeordeath situation I worry its not going to be there for me  Add to that Im not keeping one in the chamber for the same reason the police dont cruiser ready they call it So the very first thing I have to do is chamber a round  To be clear I do own shotguns and I do keep one loaded But my goto for home defense is a pistol For years it was a hammerfired pistol decocked This year replaced with a glock 34 in part because I could put an optic on it but also because I just trust the glock to sit loaded in a drawer for years and then fire when I pull the trigger  If someone has broken into my house I go for the pistol   If someone is in the process of breaking in I go for the pistol clip on a holster then also get the shotgun

Im remembering accurately anon and Im beginning to suspect that you werent shooting back then Even during the AWB ARs were common and easily available and people were putting dots on them You didnt see as many flattops back then and most people were rocking A2 handguards but its no great feat to stick an optic on the carry handle In fact Id argue that about the only optic that works correctly when mounted like that is a red dot  As for the dots themselves the most affordable ones of the era then as now were the cheap Chinese crap BSA and Tasco and such One step up got you a Kobra or some other Russian or Belarussan device from Kalinka which was arguably a bit better more durable if nothing else but much heavier If you were willing to pay more I know that there were Aimpoints around for sure I still have a CompM2 from 2005 and yes it still works and probably some others but Im sticking to what I had personal exposure to at the time  Recall that in 2006 the US military had been using the M68 for 6 years already Not everyone remembers that US red dot use on frontline weapons predates GWOT but that doesnt mean that it didnt happen I wouldnt say that theyre as mainstream as they are today but for people that had used them in the service or gun gaymers looking for a competitive edge they were not uncommon at all   It doesnt matter what the drill is  Coopers emphasis on the snapshot didnt favor one action over another The other rifle drills hes most known for rifle ten and rifle bounce probably favor the semi auto a bit which begs the question if it performed better by his metrics why did he resort to mental gymnastics in order to favor the bolt action The easy answer is cognitive dissonance but only he knew for sure and hes not going to tell us

I wouldnt say that theyre as mainstream as they are today but for people that had used them in the service or gun gaymers looking for a competitive edge they were not uncommon at all  Thats what Im saying They werent mainstream Combat veterans and gamers are a fraction of the market I know the military had been using them for a while but it hadnt filtered down to the civilian market like it has today  if it performed better by his metrics why did he resort to mental gymnastics in order to favor the bolt action  I cant speak for him but for me its like I said earlier Performance on the range is just one part of the equation and the characteristics that affect the handling of the gun are more important to me in the hunting role that the guns were primarily intended for I have ARs and similar black rifles and I could take them hunting if I wanted to but I dont because their design lends itself more to combat and sport shooting than outdoorsman stuff I think people lose sight of that when they tunnelvision on the particulars like the optics setup and magazine capacity

So merchant ships and warships are built to totally different standards Merchant ships basically lack bulkheads to the point that several were sunk in WW2 where the torpedo was a dud but the giant breach in the hull still meant that the ship sank within an hour Even a tiny destroyer escort wouldnt be a guaranteed kill with a torpedo hit crippled all but guaranteed but not guaranteed to be a kill and thats if you hit Escorts were smaller targets which could move faster and turn sharper and worst of all shoot back Submarines did attack them when the opportunity presented itself but taking out an escort wont have as much of an immediate material impact as a merchant since the important thing is the goods on the ship not as much the ship itself Also merchants were armed too Just shoot them lol isnt necessarily a smart or safe idea since a Submarine is about as well armored against gunfire as a merchant ship is In fact the merchant ship might even have bigger guns on it

cruise missiles could basically cripple China  If they successfully breech the dam it would massively fuck up several major populationindustrial areas with colossal loss of life It wouldnt grind the whole country to a complete and irrecoverable standstill since it is a big country with people and industry elsewhere but it would be a catastrophe Something comparable to a colony drop in Gunam as opposed to 911 for us Theyd be mega pissed and their nukes would work fine so all out ICBM retaliation is pretty much guaranteed   Could it be done  Its hard to say The dam approached failure from regular flooding but how close it got is speculative A conventional weapon would only need to weaken the structure but it is an awfully huge lump of concrete If its close to breaking and then gets hit then the chances are better   Why did they build it  Tons of reasons Electricity water reserves flood control All the reasons why youd build a dam only its a fuckhuge one They arent complete idiots like NK if on the balance of things it wasnt worth it they wouldnt have done it It does create very real dangers and downsides of course     Once a war breaks out its a theoretically valid target but the consequences of breaching the 3G are high enough where its comparable to a nuclear attack Its on a much larger scale that dams busted in WW2 and even then those did fuck things up for Germany significantly Of course by the time that happened 1 It was total war and if we had nukes we would have used them too 2 Germans didnt have any nukes to retaliate with  In a scenario where China is in an armed conflict but its not all out armageddon yet blowing the 3G might be an option but it would push things in that direction If nukes are flying everywhere anyway its definitely catching one If a country without nukes like Taiwan gets attacked striking back at 3G is an option that may give them comparable results

Revolvers can handle cartridges that are too powerful for most practical autoloaders to fire and are immune to a wide variety of malfunctions which has given them a reputation for strengthdependability that is confused for durability They are not really that durable because they need good cylinder to barrel alignment and functioning lockwork to operate properly Either of which can fail and is a nightmare to repair  You should therefore refrain from doing retarded shit like spinningflicking the cylinder not because it will wreck the gun right away but because doing it frequently will cause significantly accelerated wear  Its like saying  well Toyotas are reliable so when I park it I can just crash into a wall every time instead of using my brakes because it has bumpers to stop it anyway   it has shocks so I can go over speed bumps at full speed   I can drive 50 miles a day for years without any oil changes because its reliable   why car broken I thought it was reliable   Just like there are idiots that abuse and ruin perfectly fine Toyotas by being idiots there are brainlets that ruin perfectly good revolvers with their own stupidity and complain that its the guns fault

IIRC Paul Harrell tested 380FMJ on his meat target leather couch skin pork chop pectoralspork ribs oranges to simulate lung tissue pork chops on the back and behind it is the new and improved high tech fleece bullet stop and all 380 projectiles went through the target even going out the back of the 40 layer fleece bullet stop The take away from that is that 380FMJ may have too much penetration for your intended purposes and youre letting a lot of energy escape out the back of the target rather than dumping the energy into the target One reason 380 is popular is because the reduced recoil of the round enables it to be used in handgun frames that would otherwise be rather unpleasant to shoot if chambered in 9mm or 10mm This has benefits not only for recoil comfort but also the overall size of a pistol you may be attempting to conceal      Ive had my eye on the Plus model for a while do you know how it compares to the base model The dimensional differences seem negligible for twice the capacity

Thats what Im saying They werent mainstream Combat veterans and gamers are a fraction of the market I know the military had been using them for a while but it hadnt filtered down to the civilian market like it has today   Kind of the same niche market that would be flying down to Paulden to take expensive classes when you think about it  I feel like were meandering here so Ill get back to my point Lets say that I have a theory about the ideal general purpose rifle I sing its praises and I warn people about the problems with other competing products Then I design a series of drills to show what the ideal general purpose rifle is capable of it would be easy to imagine that Id designed these drills to showcase the strengths of my idea and shit on other ideas but lets say that I was completely objective and these drills were simply a good method for establishing what worked and what didnt completely without bias Now lets say that a majority of students started showing up with a product utilizing a different philosophy that generally outperformed my idea   As a reasonable competent and intellectually honest man would I refine my idea to accomodate these new observations Or would I double down on my original idea  Cooper was not an idiot He was right about a lot of things Weaver stance before widespread body armor shotgun range bands color codes etc Hell I still preach his idea about the quickly judging the weight of a rifle and Im gratified to see firsthand newer shooters understanding and adopting it I wont even say that he was wrong about the scout rifle concept but he seemed unwilling to accept that there was another way to get there beyond the way hed envisioned

Part 22  Youll want some sort of sporting rifle Some sort of semiauto for shooting multigun matches doing tactical monkeybusiness with and potentially removing intruders stepping on your property andor rights ARs are the standard in the US but AKs are cool too Pistol Caliber Carbines can be cheaper to shoot and may be good if you want something light portable and easy to carry lots of ammunition for but generally are more of a specialized tool you should look at getting later on once youve already bought a rifle Get a cheap ChiCom chest rig or a cheap ALICE LBE rig and youve reached the level of equipment most of the guys giving the US military hell for the last 73 years were at  Youll also want some sort of rifle for reaching out and touching things This doesnt need to be a 3000 highend sniping platform Any basic hunting rifle from a reputable manufacturer with a decent scope will do the job Get it in an easily available general purpose fullflavor cartridge 308 is your best bet for cost and availability but 3006 270 Win 65 Creedmore or any other standard big game cartridge will drop anything in North America from a couple hundred yards Dont skimp on the scope put at least 13 to 12 of what you put into the rifle into the scope Then youll need to go to the range and put a few hundred rounds into steel cardboard or whatever fruits or plastic bottles filled with liquid have offended you that day until you have a hard time missing the target  These four will cover you for the majority of shooting styles and from there you can figure out what you really like doing and either upgrade directly or diversify into similar but different firearms within that style If you really like the tactical stuff maybe get a handgun and some gear If you like clay shooting or bird hunting invest in a nicer shotgun Long distance shooting Get a really nice Tika Varmint rifle in a chassis with a 1000 scope on top

I appreciate the effort you put into your post but   Generally the best way to get into this unless you have one really specific discipline in mind is to get 34 guns that generally cover your bases and then move from there  is some straight up bullshit As is recommending a 4 long arms before a single pistol  From a practicality point of view a pistol is a better purchase than just about anything else If you need a gun in an emergency then chances are any gun will be enough The important thing is having that gun  any gun  when you need it Sure a shotgun might be more likely to achieve a oneshot stop and an AR is just plain better ballistically but most threats will fuck off the moment you start shooting regardless of what youre shooting with A pistol has the advantage that you can protect yourself outside your home too even if youre not planning to get a conceal carry license or start carrying daily its still worth having the option to covertly carry a gun in an emergency  For a new shooter its also worth noting that pistol ranges are often easier to find than rifle ranges  After that it depends on what someones interested in Telling someone to buy a sporting rifle a shotgun and a hunting rifle is so generic as to be useless Yeah a shotgun is versatile but if someone isnt interested in shooting birds or clays and they have a boltaction 308 for hunting then the shotgun is wasted money Similarly if OP doesnt plan on getting into longrange shooting or hunting or if hes hunting in terrain where a shotgun will do the job just fine then theres no need to buy a scoped 308 just to tick a box or whatever Even your sporting rifle category isnt necessary get an AR10 in 308 or 65 CM and you have a gun that can handle larping longrange shooting and hunting just fine

A rack grade M14 isnt particularly accurate anon That myth came from civilian shooters with tuned guns and match barrels The only things that the M14 had going for it accuracy wise are a typically decent trigger out of the box and sights that can do good work on a KD range although theyre too fragile for field use by modern standards  Likewise ARs arent particularly accurate either as fielded by the military What they have going for them are similarly good sights and improved ergonomics which can and do result in tighter groups Where you see a real difference is when you start accurizing them  Accurizing an AR  install good barrel   install good barrel   float barrel   Accurizing the M14  install good barrel   skim bed stock   RTV on the handguard   NM flash hider   black magic and sorcery   rinse and repeat every 500 rounds   Many more accurate AR15s and AR10s out there as its simpler to make them accurate and theyre easier to shoot well   t armorer

my understanding as of now is that the lower the number in MM of caliber the most powerful  No There is no single hardandfast rule when comparing caliber names You have to look up what they are actually referring to At first glance one would think that the larger bullet is more powerful If one didnt know any better it makes logical sense that a 9mm should be more powerful than a 556mm since 9  5 But whats not being said is that 9mm is a handgun round while the 556mm is a rifle round with a lot more gunpowder behind its bullet so you cant just compare the two bullet diameters Even within specific kinds of ammunition you cant make this assumption For example take common revolver cartridges 357 Magnum is significantly more powerful than 45 Long Colt even though 45  357 and if you put the two cartridges sidebyside the 45 looks bigger In this case the underlying reasoning is that the 45LC is a very old blackpowder cartridge which has relatively low pressure whereas the 357 is a lot newer cartridge using modern gunpowder and a lot higher pressure In both of these examples the smaller caliber bullet is more powerful because it has more andor more powerful gunpowder propelling it

for a really basic build using OEM   milspecneutered trigger group this is the market standard and comes stock on most rifle kits and prefabs   pretty much any Bolt carrier   any par bolt get one that is magnetically inspected and not batch tested it will help to insure quality   choice of upper there are a lot of variable designs but most are pretty close to milspec for a reason   buffer tube there are three kinds rifle carbine and pistol   rifle is the OG carbine is the one on the M4 and pistol is the same length as carbine but doesnt have the attachment point for the M4 style stock  butt stock you need to match to your buffer tube most are M4 but the fixed stocks tend to be rifle tube style   buffer and buffer spring there are basically two rifle length and carbine   the buffer matters more than the spring as a rifle buffer wont allow a carbine length buffer tube to cycle  112 vs 18 or 19 vs 17 twist rate basically if you get 17 shoot 62gr projectiles   free float vs clamshell hand guard   just get the one that matches your gas block they are sized by the gastube length you cannot use a clamshell unless you have a Dring and milspec gas block to use a free float you normally need a low profile gas block but there are some that use milspec  muzzle device  not strictly necessary but the A2 bird cage and crush washer is normally very cheap and among the better designs if you have threads on your barrel atleast get a thread protector and use either a crush washer or locktight  basically if you walk in and ask for a bare bones AR at a gun store you will get something of this and it will be fine if it isnt exactly this  some cheaper rifles that are good for starters  KP15 Complete Polymer Receiver  PSA 16 MidLength 556 NATO 17 Nitride Classic Upper With BCG  CH ODG  optic or rear iron sight   DELTON Echo 316M    probably whatever is on the wall of your local gun store

it was made in response to the 1973 war they wanted the chieftain but the british wouldnt okay a liscense to produce them if they were going to make modifications to the design  which is what made them realize they couldnt rely on the british for armor despite having used the centurion as their mainstay so they gathered up as many crews as possible to get feedback to design a tank specific to their needs and able to be built using existing infrastructure  so one of the most important things that soldiers asked for is a way to resupply in the field loading ammo through the top hatch was time consuming and couldnt be done unless you had a crane so they moved the engine to the front to allow for a rear hatch to reload ammo under fire this also addressed another common complaint which is that a lot of crews were killed while bailing out of a vehicle so the rear hatch also allowed them a way to put the bulk of the tank between them and machine guns while leaving while the engine at the front makes for a highly unbalanced design prone to tip overs and all but guarantees a Mkill it was deemed an acceptable compromise for greater combat endurance and improved crew safety  they also needed to improve survivability against shaped charges but they still had no access to composite armor so they tried to squeeze as much protection from steel as possible which resulted in the steeply angled lowprofile turret that tries to present as much angling to get that tiny bit of extra protection out of steel the engine at the front also acts puts about an extra meter of standoff between the crew and any penetrations  the merk 2 onwards did have composite armor which they added to the vehicle but its a little too late to drastically alter the shape of the vehicle but this was not a major concern since they redesigned the merkava to only have structural armor on its base with all of its armor attached via modules for ease of repair

Im a utilitarian at heart with a buy once cry once mentality so Ive definitely been stressing on it haha  I dont hate that mentality at all and somewhat share it but Ill caution you to be careful about it in the world of firearms Suppressors are one of the only places where it makes more sense given the legal BS but even there more money often doesnt mean better but rather more specialized whether thats better depends on use Like titanium stuff costs more because titanium is just way way more of a pain in the dick to work with And sure it saves weight but titanium is LESS durable then steel let alone inconel You generally dont want to let a Ti can get 700F So a high end ti can will cost more and might be perfect on a hunting rifle where you really want to shave weight innawoods but is actively the wrong material choice for range funz Or with fancy 3D flow designs which have real advantages in performance and backpressure but thats worthless on a bolt and can be much harder to repair which then leads back to legal BS  Then with stuff like sighting there is no one right answer LPVOs fixed mag  RDS holoflip mag all have their tradeoffs Spending 10x the money on an LPVO doesnt radically change it either in terms of stuff like eye box it just means nicer glass less chromatic aberration etc But youd be best off if thinking about it starting with a 300 swampfox because you may find you just dont like them and they dont fit your use cases  Anyway not to rant just saying you can end up with buy once cry anyway if you dont know what youre after and buy ultra dirt cheap first sometimes is a good idea long term But I dont think youll be upset with any of the main manufacturer decent cans I loved my first one Ive loved each one since

Could you make anti material rockets   Yes Though to get reliable detonation with a meaningfully heavy head you either need dangerously sensitive impact fuses a custom bow with an extremely high draw for higher velocity or its only going to work if it hits something very hard perfectly square  this is what you sound like  the detonator would be nontrivial but launch grenades rockets etc exist alread  the real problem is that a proper engineer with a proper shop could do it backed by some chemical engineers and lots of money but i imagine op wants something more diy i would look at the old timey sea mine chemical horn   Early mines had mechanical mechanisms to detonate them but these were superseded in the 1870s by the Hertz horn or chemical horn which was found to work reliably even after the mine had been in the sea for several years The mines upper half is studded with hollow lead protuberances each containing a glass vial filled with sulfuric acid When a ships hull crushes the metal horn it cracks the vial inside it allowing the acid to run down a tube and into a leadacid battery which until then contained no acid electrolyte This energizes the battery which detonates the explosive   Earlier forms of the detonator employed a vial of sulfuric acid surrounded by a mixture of potassium perchlorate and sugar When the vial was crushed the acid ignited the perchloratesugar mix and the resulting flame ignited the gunpowder charge   i guess a totse faggot tier type one could make at home could be made from a light bulb or something but wouldnt be the most reliable and would eat up a lot of weight left you could use for the actual charge  its still a retarded idea but only developmentally disabled tier retarded not mouthbreather low functioning tier      this is also a proble youre still looking at like 80lbs of force max for a bow that can be fired comfortably and accurately and maybe 200 for a crossbow

I mean the JP aluminum BCG is insanely light to the point of feeling like plastic in the hand but its also listed by JP as a consumable because they know what they are making There is a fixed amount of energy in a 556 round When you reduce that bolt mass the energy is still going to be there and will be translated into a much faster cyclic rate Right on so youre going to reduce your gas port size install an adjustable block or some upstream gas mitigation Now you have reduced the operational range of the gun in terms of environmental fouling or ammo variation Now what do you do about the buffer Do you eat up that increased acceleration with a heavier buffer effectively creating a similar reciprocating mass Do you juice up the spring and further retard reliability when fouling  But ill put a non lbp can on the thing and gas the fuck out of it  And then it will shoot like shit because a light mass moving fast can still carry much energy what is 556 Comparing 556 bcg massesvelocities in systems  Milspec carriers   416  same weight as milspec faster bolt velocity than milspec   SCAR  much heavier weight significantly slower bolt velocity than milspec  The 416 has the worst recoil impulse out of the bunch The gun is very harsh compared to SCAR or even Milspec DI guns  Really low mass are excellent in a gamer gun that is going to run your custom tuned handloads for a couple hundred match and then be detail cleaned Beyond that you retard the operating window of the rifle to a point where its a shiggity diggity     Most MFGs should have the same diam im sure you could find some bullshit company that makes one that doesnt fit if you want to be mad As long as youre confident that you can do that rollpin perfectly multiple times Ive seen too many guns go down due to buffer pin retainers poorly staked or walking out

I am M113 Armored Personel Carrier I was made for the next great war The War against the soviets and Russians But that war never came I am old obsolete Relegated to backguard duties For many years I have served in many places Peacekeeping they call it For years I have kept my crew safe They come and go and the places where I serve change Followed by many many years in mothballed storage I am used to it Sleeping is all right for a veteran like me   But now something disturbs my slumber  Strange voices strange language  What is this I have a new camo paint Is this woodland camo Not desert No more fighting insurgents  My environment starts to filter in This is European flatlands We are in Europe   And what is this I have new optics Thermals Lasers I have an autogun How cool is that All right calm down Ive got some new additions Upgrades My threads feel sleek well oiled after being in storage for so long Must be new ball bearings I feel stronger Young again Deadly  I hear them speak but I do not know the language But I recognize one word Ruski spoken with discontent Have the Russians returned  Friendly IFF signals fill my mind Abrams Challengers Some T80s and T72s but with friendly tags Captured and put to use   Is that why I am once more awakened Is it finally the time Time to fight the Russians My engine roars to life Finally I am M113 APC and this is what I was made for

The Battle of the Bees in WW1 was a pretty lulzy roller coaster  Bongs invade German Tanzania at the start of the war all the other German colonies have surrendered more or less effortlessly so not much thought is put into the invasion force   a few Royal Navy ships sail into Tanga the largest port city and send out a call for surrender   the German governor agrees to surrender and tells the British they can sail right into port and occupy the town dont even bother landing your troops on the beach itll be a waste of time   hmmmmmm that sounds suspicious we should definitely land our troops on the beach then   the bongs and their infantry force mainly comprising of Indians take so long landing and sweeping the harbor for mines that a call for help is able to be sent out to the Tanzanian garrison who commandeered a bunch of trains and rushed to the citys defense and were able to arrive before the bongs decided to push off the beaches as the British commander had ordered the Indians to unload his personal household furnishings first before their equipment   finally the British advance inland and HOLY SHIT ITS A WHOLE BRIGADE OF GERMANS JUST CHILLING IN THE TREE LINE   from the beach to the town was a large plantation field which had to be crossed The German colonial troops waited until a majority of the Indian first wave was walking across in the open before opening fire   the Sirs take heavy casualties and their advance is completely stalled The survivors take cover in irrigation ditches and are content to just chill there and wait for naval gunfire to break up the German lines   this plan might have worked were it not for the fact that amateur beekeeping was a favorite pastime among the German colonists and the large empty field close to town was a prime spot for their nest hutches which were now riddled by gunfire   the bees inside began to swarm out and attack the troops taking cover underneath who completely routed back to the landing beaches
